frameDefinitions: A volitional  Agent is responding to a State_of_affairs by performing some Action.
This scenario describes a series of Events, associated with a single Participant, i.e., the history of the Participant.
An Arguer presents a Content, along with Support, to an Addressee.
A Speaker communicates a message stating an Item's membership in a Category, i.e., asserts that the Item has the defining characteristics of the Category.
A Question about the reason or cause of a known State_of_affairs is presented as being answered by the existence of a particular Fact.
frameExamples: And was that your <t>reason</t> for becoming an actor ?
We've been worried about our recent hire's <t><fex name='Events'>history</fex></t> of deceiving employers.
Jan <t>argued</t> that the evidence was inadmissable.
He <t>depicted</t> his involvement as merely peripheral.
Ruby's orange vest marked with the words 'service dog' <t>accounts</t> for why the 3-year-old goes along.
listRoleDefinitions: The person who responds to a <fen>State_of_Affairs</fen> by performing some <fen>Action</fen>.
The action that the <fen>Agent</fen> performs in response to a <fen>State_of_Affairs</fen>.
The eventuality  that motivates the <fen>Agent</fen>'s performing a particular <fen>Action</fen> in response to it.

The <fen>Participant</fen> is either an active participant in all of the <fen>Events</fen> (e.g., Agent or Patient), or is more peripherally associated with the <fen>Events</fen> (e.g., Location or Topic).
The <fen>Events</fen> which the <fen>Participant</fen> is a part of. This role is used to mark the frame-evoking element.
When the <fen>Events</fen> concerning the <fen>Participant</fen> occured.
A force, process, or event that produces an effect.
Agents in a joint or reciprocal action (e.g. exchange)
A positive or negative evaluation of the Phenomenon.
An entity which participates in a <fen>Cause</fen>, perhaps volitionally and perhaps not.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the event occurs.
Where the event takes place.

The <fen>Arguer</fen> wants the <fen>Addressee</fen> to entertain the <fen>Content</fen>, which can be a proposition to be believed or a course of action to be taken, based on the <fen>Support</fen> presented.
The <fen>Arguer</fen> presents the <fen>Content</fen> before the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
The Time at which an <fen>Arguer</fen> makes an argument for the <fen>Content</fen>.
This role identifies the location where an argument is made by an <fen>Arguer</fen>.
The individual that communicates the message concerning the <fen>Category</fen> of an <fen>Item</fen>.
The class of entities with characteristics that match those of the <fen>Item</fen> according to the portrayal of the <fen>Speaker</fen>.
The entity that the <fen>Speaker</fen> portrays as belonging to a <fen>Category</fen>.
The piece of text in which a <fen>Speaker</fen> communicates their categorization of the <fen>Item</fen>.
The point in time at which the <fen>Speaker</fen> makes a characterization of the <fen>Item</fen>.
The location at which the <fen>Speaker</fen> characterizes the <fen>Item</fen>
A <fen>Fact</fen> which can be connected by a chain of reasoning to the <fen>State_of_affairs</fen>.
A <fen>Fact</fen> whose cause is under consideration.
An open proposition concerning the cause of the <fen>State_of_affairs</fen>.
listRoleExamples: I find that all my reasons <fex>for postponing giving birth</fex> still apply
My reason is <fex>that our cities are now designed round the motor car</fex>
We've been worried about <fex>our recent hire's</fex> history of deceiving employers.
We will focus on events in her recent <fex>history</fex>.
<fex>That one stone</fex>, apparently, caused the avalanche that engulfed square miles of forest.
Jan argued <fex>that the evidence was inadmissable</fex>.
<fex>Jan</fex> argued that the evidence was inadmissable.
The government argued <fex>in August</fex> that the prisoners should not be released
The young men will be arguing their policies <fex>in the school auditorium</fex>.
However, <fex>'A Brief History of Medicine'</fex> characterizes influenza as the most deadly plague, overall.
<fex>This fact</fex> alone explains the Sun/climate anomaly.
Do increased proinsulin concentrations explain <fex>the excess risk of coronary heart disease in diabetic and prediabetic subjects</fex>?
The fact that this remained in Pandora's box explains <fex>why men have hope</fex>.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: the first Sunday of Lent in 2008
the Sisters of Charity of Nevers
